data.title: Decent dim sum
data.text:
We came here for dim sum today around noon.  It was easy to get a table and the place was decorated pretty nicely.  The dim sum ordering process here was different from what we were used to.  Instead of picking from wandering food carts, we chose our selection from a reusable writable menu.  The positive aspect of this was that we can see all that is offered and our dishes are made to order.  The negative aspect was that we would be committed to what we ordered and there would be wait for each individual dish to come out.

The dim sum dishes itself was decent.  There were a few items here that we did not encountered at the other nearby dim sum place.  We liked the pork ribs with noodle rolls dish.  However, we were a bit disappointed with the vegetarian noodle roll dish as the roll was a bit watery.

data.title: Great Cantonese seafood restaurant
data.text: Excellent Cantonese seafood restaurant outside of Chinatown. All the dishes we ordered, pork, beef, duck or seafood were all cooked really well. The most surprising thing, in a good way, is that the portions were huge. Service was very good as well. Great overall value!!!

data.title: Not impress at all
data.text:
I was here twice for dinner, not dim sum or hot pot sushi buffet, I ordered by dishes.
I didn't have dim sum here it is because my friend told me is very average. I was going to give their hot pot + Sushi buffet a try but I turn my head around when I saw the not so fresh seafood sitting the counter when the sushi chef walk away. Clearly sushi is not their specialty.
Now the dishes items, first time when I visit them was a month ago it wasn't great but we give them another try because maybe it was just a  one time thing, oh boy am I was wrong. 
Food come to our table very slow, it took them 25 minutes to deliver our first dish it is very disappointment when you think about how fast normally to get your food from a Chinese restaurant.
Food was not great, I can tell they didn't spend enough time seasoning their meat, shrimp was on the dry side and vegetable was over cook. 

I wont visit this place again because there are so many options around the area, but it seems to me that in Malden every Chinese food is bad because the don't pay attention to their food, they just want to make money!

data.title: Good Chinese food, bad service!
data.text: Three families came together for a feast and the food did not fail!  Seafood was very good from Bird Nest basket, walnut shrimps, softshell craps, salt/ pepper calamari, stir fry lobster, etc.  The fried tofu is one of the best with chives.  One dish we did not like was the Whole steam fish.  It was over cooked and bland.  Children loved the sesame beef, sesame chicken, orange chicken/beef, anything sweet.  I served as the waitress for ourselves, getting more cutlery, water, rice, etc.  This is our 3rd visits and nothing have changed as far as not enough wait staffs.  They needed another half a dozen more staffs, at least.  A couple dishes were served when we were all on our feet to leave.

data.title: Nice new dim sum place in Malden
data.text: Malden, MA, has become the branch of Boston's chinatown. One of the new additions there is Yong Yong restaurant, which offers dim sum style food on top of regular menu. The dim sum has a pretty good variety and the food we tried tasted good. The restaurant is clean and the service is quick. Overall my family and I enjoyed our meal there and would love to visit again.

data.title: Great new option - all you can eat "hot pot" Chinese in Malden
data.text: We were hungry, it was after 8, and my partner had already promised she would buy since it was payday.  A few days earlier I had spotted this new spot in Malden center, at the intersection of Eastern Ave and Ferry St.  We were not very familiar with "hot pot" but it seemed like a break from the ordinary so we went.  We were glad we did.  The place is really 2 or maybe 3 restaurants in one, but all the customers were sitting in the "hot pot" side so it was the obvious choice.  We opted for the "yin-yang" version (half spicy/half tame) for the broth.  You select from a variety of meats, seafood, and vegetables.  They bring the "hot pot" broth and set the pot on a stove-top built into your table.  It started boiling pretty quickly, and they brought out our selections so we could start cooking and eating.  This is an "all you can eat format", and includes sushi as well.  We had a spicy salmon roll from that list, but the star was the "cook your own dinner" in the "hot pot".  The food comes out with the meats sliced very thin and frozen.  The shrimp were whole and frozen too.  It was fun and great.  It took us a while to recognize that there were some utensils on the table (big spoon and slotted big spoon) to aid the cooks, so we struggled a bit at first.  It also was a while before we tried the "hot-pot sauce", which turned out to be a soy-ginger flavoring which was excellent.  The other customers were nearly all in small friends or family groups, eating and talking and having fun.  We did too.  There was a big screen with something going on in Chinese, and that ethnic group made up over 80% of the customers, which we think was a very good sign about the place.  If you are interested in a bit of a culinary adventure we recommend this place.  I expect we will be back soon and will be bringing some of our friends with us.  Enjoy!
